body:
Comment 45: 
The code is open sourceâ€”go get code.google.com/p/redwood-filter. The configuration is
proprietary, but I will share it for debugging purposes. The configuration directory
(attached) should be extracted as /etc/redwood. 

I am not including my SSL certificates, so you'll need to create new ones. Put them at
the paths specified in redwood.conf, on the tls-cert and tls-key lines (or change those
lines to point to your certificates). Import your SSL certificates into your browser as
trusted roots.

Create the /var/log/redwood directory.

Run redwood. Set your browser's HTTP and HTTPS proxies to {{the server where you're
running redwood}}:6502. Browse around on the web. Many sites will be inaccessible;
that's the point of the program. When you run into a blocked site, just try something
else. Most sites related to programming should be available.

The heavier the load the server is under, the more likely it is to crash. My crash this
morning happened while I was running portupgrade -a.
Attachments: 1. redwood.zip (548000 bytes)
